title: Algebra 1 - Functions: SAT Module 2 Style (US Context)

problems.title: Student ID System
problems.context: Lincoln High School in California uses a digital ID system for its 1,500 students. Each student receives a unique 7-digit ID number that maps to their lunch account. The cafeteria scanner reads the ID and automatically charges the student's account. The system processes 300 transactions per lunch period.
questions: a) Why is the relationship between student and ID number a function?
b) If one student could have multiple IDs, would this still be a function?
c) Can the cafeteria system map an ID back to exactly one student?

problems.title: Amazon Prime Shipping
problems.context: Amazon Prime offers different shipping speeds based on item weight. Items under 2 pounds ship for $5.99, 2-5 pounds for $8.99, and 5-10 pounds for $12.99. Orders over 10 pounds require special handling at $19.99. The pricing structure remains constant throughout the year. A customer orders three items weighing 1.5, 3.2, and 7.8 pounds.
questions: a) Calculate the shipping cost for each item.
b) Would the same weight always result in the same shipping cost?
c) Explain why this shipping system represents a function.

problems.title: Uber Pricing Algorithm
problems.context: Uber's base fare in Manhattan is $2.55 plus $0.35 per minute and $1.75 per mile. During peak hours (7-9 AM and 5-7 PM), surge pricing multiplies the total by 1.5x. A rider travels 4.2 miles in 12 minutes during morning rush hour. The app calculates the fare automatically using these consistent rules.
questions: a) Calculate the fare before surge pricing.
b) What is the final fare with surge pricing?
c) Identify the domain and range of this pricing function.

problems.title: 401(k) Retirement Matching
problems.context: TechCorp matches employee 401(k) contributions: 100% match up to 3% of salary, then 50% match for the next 2% of salary. An employee earning $80,000 annually wants to maximize the company match. The IRS limit for 401(k) contributions is $22,500 per year.
questions: a) Calculate the maximum company match amount.
b) What percentage should the employee contribute to maximize the match?
c) Write the matching function M(x) where x is the contribution percentage.

problems.title: Starbucks Rewards Program
problems.context: Starbucks rewards members earn 2 stars per dollar spent. At 25 stars, they get a free customization; at 100 stars, a free handcrafted drink; at 200 stars, a free lunch item. Sarah spends an average of $6.50 per visit and visits 3 times per week. She started the month with 45 stars.
questions: a) How many stars does Sarah earn per week?
b) When will she reach her first free drink (100 stars)?
c) Express her total stars as a function of weeks: S(w).

problems.title: Progressive Tax Brackets
problems.context: The US federal tax system uses progressive brackets. For single filers in 2024: 10% on income up to $11,000, 12% on $11,001-$44,725, 22% on $44,726-$95,375. A software engineer earns $75,000 annually. The tax calculation applies different rates to different portions of income.
questions: a) Calculate tax owed on each bracket.
b) What is the total tax owed?
c) What is the effective tax rate?
d) Sketch the tax function T(x) for incomes $0-$100,000.

problems.title: Netflix Subscription Tiers
problems.context: Netflix offers three plans: Basic at $6.99/month (1 screen), Standard at $15.49/month (2 screens), and Premium at $22.99/month (4 screens). A family of 5 wants to minimize cost while allowing everyone to watch simultaneously during peak evening hours. They analyze their viewing patterns over a month.
questions: a) What's the minimum cost to support 5 simultaneous viewers?
b) Calculate the cost per screen for each plan.
c) Is the relationship between price and screens linear?

problems.title: Tesla Supercharger Pricing
problems.context: Tesla Superchargers price electricity based on time of day. Off-peak (11 PM - 7 AM): $0.24/kWh, Mid-peak (7 AM - 2 PM, 9 PM - 11 PM): $0.36/kWh, Peak (2 PM - 9 PM): $0.48/kWh. A Model 3 with a 75 kWh battery charges from 20% to 80%. The driver starts charging at 1:30 PM and it takes 45 minutes.
questions: a) How many kWh are needed?
b) What is the charging cost?
c) How much would the driver save by charging at 11 PM instead?

problems.title: Compound Interest Savings
problems.context: A high-yield savings account offers 4.5% APY compounded monthly. An investor deposits $10,000 and plans to save for a house down payment. The compound interest formula is A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt), where P is principal, r is annual rate, n is compounding frequency, and t is time in years.
questions: a) Calculate the balance after 1, 2, and 3 years.
b) How long to reach $12,000?
c) Compare with simple interest earnings over 3 years.

problems.title: Credit Card APR
problems.context: A credit card charges 24.99% APR compounded daily. A customer has a $5,000 balance and makes only minimum payments of 2% of the balance each month. The daily rate is APR/365. Interest compounds on the remaining balance after each payment.
questions: a) Calculate the daily interest rate.
b) What's the first month's interest charge (30 days)?
c) How much of the first minimum payment goes to principal?
d) Express balance as a function after n months of minimum payments.

problems.title: Stock Options Vesting
problems.context: A Silicon Valley startup offers employees stock options with a 4-year vesting schedule. 25% vests after year 1 (cliff), then 1/48 vests each month. An engineer receives 4,800 options at a strike price of $10. Current stock price is $25.
questions: a) How many options vest at the 1-year cliff?
b) Create function V(m) for vested options after m months.
c) What's the current value of vested options after 18 months?
d) When will 75% of options be vested?

problems.title: Mortgage Amortization
problems.context: A 30-year fixed mortgage of $400,000 at 7% interest has monthly payments of $2,661. Early payments go mostly to interest. The monthly interest is calculated on the remaining balance. Each payment reduces the principal, decreasing future interest charges.
questions: a) Calculate the first month's interest.
b) How much of the first payment goes to principal?
c) What's the remaining balance after the first payment?
d) Find total interest paid over 30 years.

problems.title: Gym Membership Economics
problems.context: Planet Fitness offers $10/month membership with a $39 annual fee. LA Fitness charges $35/month with no annual fee. Gold's Gym has a $199 annual prepaid option. A customer plans to work out consistently for at least 8 months but is unsure about the full year.
questions: a) Write cost functions C(m) for each gym (m = months).
b) At what point does Planet Fitness become cheaper than LA Fitness?
c) For 8 months, which option is most economical?
d) Find the break-even point for Gold's Gym.

problems.title: DoorDash Delivery Fees
problems.context: DoorDash charges based on distance: $2.99 for 0-2 miles, $4.99 for 2-5 miles, $6.99 for 5-8 miles. Additionally, there's a 15% service fee on the food order and a 10% tip (calculated pre-fee). A customer orders $45 worth of food from a restaurant 3.5 miles away.
questions: a) Calculate the delivery fee based on distance.
b) What's the service fee amount?
c) Calculate the tip amount.
d) Find the total payment.

problems.title: Electric Vehicle Range
problems.context: A Tesla Model 3 has an EPA range of 358 miles. Real-world range varies with speed: at 55 mph, efficiency is 100%; at 65 mph, it's 90%; at 75 mph, it's 78%. Highway driving also reduces range by temperature: -10% at 32°F, -20% at 0°F. A driver plans a 280-mile trip at 70 mph in 40°F weather.
questions: a) Estimate efficiency at 70 mph using linear interpolation.
b) Calculate the adjusted range at 70 mph.
c) Will the driver complete the trip without charging?
d) What's the maximum safe speed for this trip?

problems.title: College Tuition Growth
problems.context: State university tuition has grown from $8,000 in 2014 to $13,500 in 2024. A family with a newborn wants to save for college starting in 2042. If tuition continues growing at the same rate, they need to project future costs. They plan to use a 529 education savings plan.
questions: a) Calculate the annual growth rate.
b) Project tuition for 2042.
c) What function T(y) models tuition in year y?
d) How much should they save monthly at 6% return?

problems.title: Airline Dynamic Pricing
problems.context: Delta Airlines adjusts ticket prices based on demand. A flight from NYC to LA starts at $250 sixty days before departure. Price increases by $5 per day for the first 30 days, then $15 per day for the next 20 days, and $40 per day for the final 10 days. A traveler books 18 days before departure.
questions: a) Create the pricing function P(d) where d = days before departure.
b) Calculate the ticket price 18 days before departure.
c) How much would the traveler save by booking 25 days early?
d) On which day does the price exceed $500?

problems.title: Solar Panel Efficiency
problems.context: Solar panels lose efficiency in extreme temperatures. Peak efficiency (100%) occurs at 77°F. Efficiency drops by 0.4% for each degree above 77°F. A California installation experiences temperatures from 65°F to 105°F throughout the year. Panels produce 400W at peak efficiency.
questions: a) Write the efficiency function E(T) where T is temperature.
b) Calculate power output at 95°F.
c) At what temperature does efficiency drop to 90%?
d) Find daily energy production if temperature follows T(h) = 77 + 20sin((h-6)π/12).

problems.title: Basketball Free Throws
problems.context: A basketball follows a parabolic path. When shot from 15 feet away at 45°, the ball's height is h(x) = -0.08x² + 1.2x + 7, where x is horizontal distance and h is height in feet. The rim is 10 feet high. The shooter wants to optimize their shooting angle.
questions: a) What's the maximum height of the ball?
b) At what distance does it reach maximum height?
c) Does the ball go through the rim at x = 15?
d) Find the margin of error (height above rim).

problems.title: iPhone Depreciation
problems.context: An iPhone 15 Pro costs $1,199 new. It depreciates following D(t) = 1199(0.75)^t where t is years. Insurance covers replacement if value drops below $300. Trade-in programs offer 50% of current value. A user wants to optimize their upgrade cycle.
questions: a) Calculate value after 1, 2, and 3 years.
b) When does value drop below insurance threshold?
c) What's the trade-in value after 18 months?
d) Compare total cost of upgrading every 2 vs 3 years over 6 years.

problems.title: COVID Exponential Growth
problems.context: In early 2020, COVID cases doubled every 3 days. A county started with 10 confirmed cases. The formula is C(t) = 10 × 2^(t/3) where t is days. The hospital capacity is 500 beds, with 20% reserved for COVID. Contact tracing becomes impossible above 1,000 cases.
questions: a) Write the growth function C(t).
b) When will cases exceed hospital COVID capacity?
c) When does contact tracing become impossible?
d) What's the daily growth rate?

problems.title: Bitcoin Mining Difficulty
problems.context: Bitcoin mining difficulty adjusts every 2,016 blocks (≈2 weeks) to maintain 10-minute block times. If blocks are mined 20% faster than target, difficulty increases by 20%. A mining operation's profit depends on hash rate, electricity cost ($0.12/kWh), and Bitcoin price ($45,000).
questions: a) If current difficulty is D, what's new difficulty after 20% faster mining?
b) How does profit scale with difficulty?
c) At what Bitcoin price does mining become unprofitable?
d) Model difficulty growth over n adjustment periods.

problems.title: Spotify Streaming Royalties
problems.context: Spotify pays artists $0.003-$0.005 per stream, averaging $0.004. An artist needs $50,000 annual income. They have 10,000 monthly listeners who stream their songs an average of 15 times per month. Revenue splits 70% to artist, 30% to label.
questions: a) Calculate monthly streaming revenue.
b) What's the artist's share after label split?
c) How many monthly streams needed for target income?
d) Create function I(L,S) for income based on listeners and streams.

problems.title: Gig Economy Optimization
problems.context: A driver works for both Uber (65% of rides, $18/hour average) and DoorDash (35% of time, $22/hour average). Gas costs $4/gallon, car gets 28 mpg, and they drive 25 miles per hour worked. They want to earn $1,000/week after gas expenses.
questions: a) Calculate weighted average hourly earning.
b) What's the hourly gas expense?
c) Find net hourly income.
d) How many hours needed for $1,000 weekly goal?

problems.title: YouTube Ad Revenue
problems.context: A YouTuber's channel growth follows subscribers S(t) = 1000 × 1.15^t where t is months. Ad revenue is $2 per 1,000 views. Videos average 10% of subscriber count in views. They post 4 videos monthly. Sponsorships become available at 100,000 subscribers.
questions: a) Model subscriber growth S(t).
b) When will they reach 100,000 subscribers?
c) Calculate monthly ad revenue after 12 months.
d) Project total first-year earnings.

problems.title: Stock Market Returns
problems.context: The S&P 500 historically returns 10% annually with volatility. An investor uses dollar-cost averaging, investing $500 monthly. After 20 years, they plan to retire. Historical data shows positive returns in 73% of years. Compound growth formula: FV = PMT × ((1+r)^n - 1)/r.
questions: a) Calculate future value with 10% annual return.
b) What if returns average only 7%?
c) Find total contributions vs. investment gains.
d) Model probability of reaching $500,000.

problems.title: Health Insurance Deductibles
problems.context: A high-deductible health plan has a $3,000 deductible, then covers 80% until out-of-pocket maximum of $7,000. Monthly premium is $250. A traditional plan has $500 deductible, 90% coverage, $5,000 max, but costs $450/month. An employee has expected annual medical costs of $8,000.
questions: a) Calculate total cost for each plan with $8,000 medical bills.
b) At what medical cost do plans break even?
c) Model total cost function TC(x) for each plan.
d) Which plan is better for chronic conditions?

problems.title: Real Estate ROI
problems.context: A rental property costs $300,000 with 20% down. Mortgage is 7% for 30 years. Monthly rent is $2,500. Expenses: mortgage $1,798, property tax $400, insurance $150, maintenance $200. Property appreciates 3% annually. Rent increases 2% yearly.
questions: a) Calculate monthly cash flow.
b) What's the cap rate (NOI/purchase price)?
c) Project property value after 5 years.
d) Model total return including appreciation.

problems.title: Carbon Footprint Calculator
problems.context: Carbon emissions: driving produces 404g CO₂/mile, flying 90g CO₂/mile, home electricity 0.38kg CO₂/kWh. A household drives 12,000 miles/year, flies 8,000 miles, uses 900 kWh/month. Carbon offsets cost $50/ton. They want to be carbon neutral.
questions: a) Calculate annual emissions from each source (in kg).
b) Find total annual carbon footprint (in tons).
c) What's the cost to offset their emissions?
d) If they reduce driving by 30%, how much do they save on offsets?

problems.title: Financial Independence Formula
problems.context: The FIRE (Financial Independence Retire Early) formula uses the 4% rule: you need 25× annual expenses saved. A couple spends $72,000/year. They save $3,000/month in index funds earning 8% annually. Current savings: $150,000. They want to retire when portfolio supports their lifestyle.
questions: a) Calculate their FIRE target number.
b) Model portfolio growth: P(t) = ?
c) When will they reach financial independence?
d) How does increasing savings by $500/month affect timeline?
